items.description: River Thames and its tributaries from Days Lock to above Pangbourne

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thames, Lady Brook, Ewelme Stream, Mill Brook, West Hagbourne Stream, Hakkas Brook, Cholsey Brook, Kibble Ditch

items.message:
Property flooding is not expected. River levels on the Thames and its tributaries remain high. Flooding of low lying land, roads and  property is expected to continue overnight 24/09/2024. The River Thames will continue to rise slowly in the coming days. 
Light showers are forecast today, with heavier rain forecast tomorrow 25/09/24 which could cause further flood impacts.  
Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens in the area and we are closely monitoring the situation. We are operating our weirs on the Thames to manage flood risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 25/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Kennet and its tributaries from Berwick Bassett down to Newbury

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Kennet, River Og, River Aldbourne, Froxfield Stream, River Dun, River Shalbourne

items.description: River Churn and its tributaries

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels contimue to rise on the lower River Cherwell following recent heavy rain. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected overnight, 24/09/2024, especially in areas closest to the River Cherwell between Heyford and Oxford.
Light showers are forecast today, with heavier rain forecast tomorrow 25/09/24 which could cause further flood impacts.    
Our staff have been checking and clearing trash screens in the area and we are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 25/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but have started to fall on the River Evenlode following yesterday's  heavy rain. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue overnight 24/09/2024.
No further rainfall is forecast overnight, but heavy showers are forecast tomorrow and river levels on the Rivers Glyme and Evenlode remain sensitive to further rainfall.    
Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens in the area and we are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 25/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames for the Abingdon area
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising on the River Thames as a result of very heavy rainfall yesterday. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible this evening and overnight in the Abingdon and Culham areas. Today is forecast to be mainly dry with heavy showers forecast tomorrow. We expect river levels to continue to rise slowly.  Our staff are managing weirs on the River Thames to reduce flood risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 25/09/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and tributaries from Buscot Wick down to Kings Lock
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising on the River Thames as a result of heavy rainfall yesterday. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected today 24/09/24, especially in the Tadpole Bridge area. Today is forecast to be mainly dry, with some light showers. Tomorrow's forecast is for heavier showers. We expect river levels to remain high but stable.  Our staff are managing weirs on the River Thames to reduce flood risk.  Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 25/09/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising along the upper River Ray in response to heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected from this evening, 23/09/2024 and overnight, especially in areas closest to the River Ray between Lower Arncott and Islip. 
Further heavy rainfall is forecast overnight, clearing by morning. River levels are expected to rise through the night as water moves downstream. Levels in the Lower Arncott area are expected to stabilise overnight, while levels in the Islip area will continue to rise into tomorrow.     
Our staff have been checking and clearing trash screens in the area and we are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 24/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Colne Brook at Iver and Colnbrook

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels on the Colne Brook are high due to recent heavy rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Colne Brook and Lower Colne, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Colnbrook Village, Poyle, Albany Park, High Street, Mill Street, Fawsley Close and Myrtle Close.

Further rainfall is forecast for today, Wednesday 25th September, where river levels are expected to rise. 

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and checking rivers for blockages. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 6pm today, Wednesday 25th September, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and its small tributaries from Calcutt to Lechlade

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thames, Blunsdon Brook, Water Eaton Brook, Marston Meysey Brook, Share Ditch, Bydemill Brook, Westrop Brook, Downington Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising on the River Thames as a result of heavy rainfall yesterday. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected this afternoon and overnight 24/09/24, especially in the Hannington Bridge area. Today is forecast to be mainly dry, with some light showers. Tomorrow's forecast is for heavier showers. We expect river levels to remain high over the coming days . Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 25/09/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Pangbourne to Purley
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are rising on the River Thames as a result of heavy rainfall over the weekend and earlier this week, therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected today, Wednesday 25/09/2024. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24-48 hours. We expect river levels to continue rising slowly over the next few days. We are monitoring the situation and our staff are managing weirs on the River Thames to reduce flood risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this afternoon, 25/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thame, Horsenden Stream and Chalgrove Brook

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thame, Horsenden Stream, Chalgrove Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is expected. A Flood Warning is in force for the Thames at Dorchester. River levels are rising along much of the River Thame and as a result of yesterday's heavy rain. Therefore, flooding of low lying land, roads and property is expected to continue overnight 24/09/2024, especially in the areas closest to Dorchester. 
No further rainfall is forecast overnight, but heavy showers are forecast tomorrow. We expect river levels along the Thame to rise slowly overnight in response as water moves downstream.
Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens in the area. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 25/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Pang from East Ilsley to Pangbourne and Sulham Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high on the River Pang  and Sulham Brook following recent heavy rain but have now started to stabilise or fall slowly in some places. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected overnight, 24/09/2024. 
Light showers are forecast today, with heavier rain forecast tomorrow 25/09/24 which could cause further flood impacts.     
Our staff have been checking and clearing trash screens in the area and we are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 25/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Colne and Frays River

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hertfordshire, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels remain high on the Lower River Colne and Frays River. 
Flooding may continue to affect low-lying land and roads, particularly in the Thorney Mill Road and Cricketfield Road areas, which may impact Riverside Mobile Home Park.

Further rain is forecast for today, Wednesday 25th September, and river levels may rise further. 

We are closely monitoring the situation and checking rivers for blockages. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and monitor local water levels and weather conditions.

This message will be updated by 6pm today, Wednesday 25th September, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dikler from Condicote to Little Rissington
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels have now started to fall on the River Dikler following yesterday's heavy rain. Therefore, no further flooding of low lying land and roads is expected.  
No further rainfall is forecast tonight but tomorrow's forecast is for heavy showers and levels do remain sensitive to further rain.   
Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens in the area and we are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 25/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are rising on the River Thames as a result of heavy rainfall over the weekend and earlier this week, therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected today, Wednesday 25/09/2024. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24-48 hours. We expect river levels to continue rising slowly over the next few days. We are monitoring the situation and our staff are managing weirs on the River Thames to reduce flood risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message: River levels are rising at the Lilbourne river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne. No further rainfall is forecast. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 12:00 on 25/09/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Sow and River Penk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.message:
River levels remain high at the Milford River gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue today, 24/09/24.  We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Sow between Great Bridgeford and Shugborough, the River Penk between Coven and Stafford, the Sandyford Brook, the Rising Brook, the Ridings Brook and the Saredon Brook.   
No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow, 25/09/2024.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 25/09/24, or as the situation changes

items.description: Tern and Perry catchments
items.message:
River levels have risen at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding continues.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.   
River levels have started to fall slowly but could remain high for the remainder of the week as a result of further forecast rainfall over the next 24 to 48 hours. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services and Local Authorities.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 09:00 on 26/09/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
River levels are high at the Torksey river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding to low-lying roads and farmland remains. 
Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road. 
Further heavy rainfall is forecast for this evening, Wednesday 25/09/2024, into Thursday. We expect river levels to remain high until Thursday evening, 26/09/2024.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 17:00 today, 25/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Soar in Leicestershire
items.message:
River levels are slowly rising at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road and Sileby Mill road, and farmlands at Cossington, Sileby, Barrow, Quorndon and Cotes.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until Friday 27/09/2024.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 17:00 this afternoon, 25/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent in Derbyshire
items.message:
River levels remain high but are now slowly falling at the Willington Cableway river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane.

Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours, we expect river levels to rise again following this rainfall. 

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, 26/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Medway
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
Further heavy rainfall is forecast tomorrow but no further flooding is expected for now.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Riseley Brook in Bedford Borough
items.message:
River levels are falling but remain high following recent rainfall.  

Flooding is possible.  

Areas most at risk are around the Riseley Brook from Riseley to Pertenhall.  

Further rainfall is forecast for Wednesday evening which may see river levels rise again at the Riseley telemetry station. 

Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  

We are monitoring the situation. 

We will update this message by 6pm today, 25/09/2024.

items.description: Bear Brook and tributaries in the Aylesbury area, including Wendover and Weston Turville
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels on the Bear Brook remain high in Aylesbury but have started falling slowly following heavy rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is therefore expected to continue overnight 23/09/2024 and into tomorrow, especially in the areas closest to the Bear Brook in the urban reaches through Aylesbury. 
Light showers are forecast today, with heavier rain forecast tomorrow 25/09/24 which could cause further flood impacts.  
Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens in the area and we are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. his message will be updated tomorrow morning, 25/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Bristol Avon area
items.message: The situation is improving on Tuesday the 24th September and river levels are falling slowly but they remain high. Further rainfall is expected on Wednesday and Thursday, it is not expected to cause flood warnings to be issued. We are monitoring the situation.

items.description: River Dene in South East Warwickshire
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary. Our incident response staff are actively monitoring river levels and the weather forecast.

items.description: River Lee at Hertford
items.message:
River levels remain high on the River Lee due to recent heavy rainfall. 

The Environment Agency and contractors have been in attendance at Stanstead Radial Gate, manually accommodating high flows. Flooding may continue to affect locations near the River Lee, particularly around Stanstead Lock and Tumbling Bay.

Some showers are expected on Wednesday 25th September, so we may see rivers rise again.

We are monitoring the situation closely.

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 6pm on Wednesday 25th September, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Eden and Eden Brook
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days but no further flooding is expected for now.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings as necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Burton Trent
Upper River Great Ouse in Northamptonshire, Oxfordshire and Buckinghamshire

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Milton Keynes, Oxfordshire, West Northamptonshire

items.message:
River levels are falling but remain high downstream after recent heavy rainfall.  

Flooding is possible for the next few days. 

Areas most at risk are those around the River Great Ouse from Brackley to Haversham, including Padbury Brook. 

Further rainfall is forecast for Wednesday evening which will keep river levels high. 

Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  

We are monitoring the situation. 

We will update this message by 6pm today, 25/09/2024.

items.description: River Tove in Northamptonshire
items.message:
River levels are falling at Cappenham but remain high downstream after recent heavy rainfall.  

Flooding is possible for the next few days.    

Areas most at risk are around the River Tove between Towcester to Cosgrove, including Silverstone Brook and the Stoke Bruerne Marina. Move cars out of this flood risk area.    

Further rainfall is forecast for Wednesday evening which will keep river levels high. 

Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  

We are monitoring the situation. 

We will update this message by 6pm today, 25/09/2024.

items.description: River Avon in Worcestershire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. No further significant rainfall is forecast in the next 24 hours. 
We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: River Dene at Walton
Mid Bristol Avon area

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message: River levels on the Bristol Avon at Bradford on Avon continue to slowly rise due to the heavy rain experienced on the 23rd September 2024. We are not expecting flood warnings today or tomorrow, we continue to monitor the situation. Currently areas most at risk include low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Consider putting your flood plan into action. This message will be updated at 18:00 on the 24/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Nene
items.message: Over the last 48 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the Upper River Nene area. This means that the River Nene has risen, leading to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts also indicate that further flooding inside properties is not likely and therefore a flood warning has been removed for areas near the Dallington Brook and Brampton Branch in Northampton. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 17:00 on 25/09/2024, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Middle Nene

floodArea.county: Cambridgeshire, North Northamptonshire, Peterborough, West Northamptonshire

items.message: Over the last 48 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the Middle Nene area. This means that the River Nene has risen, which will lead to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties is possible and therefore flood warnings may be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 17:00 on 25/09/2024, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: River Leam and River Itchen
items.message: River levels are rising at the Southam, Eathorpe and Kites Hardwick river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible later today, 24/09/24. We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leam between Grandborough and Leamington including Kites Hardwick, Birdingbury, Marton, Eathorpe, Hunningham and Offchurch and the River Itchen between Southam and Marton including Long Itchington. No further rainfall is forecast. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 12:00 on 25/09/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Great Ouse in Cambridgeshire from Brampton to Earith
items.message:
River levels are still rising in response to recent heavy rainfall.  

Flooding is possible for the next few days.   

Areas most at risk are around the River Great Ouse from Brampton to Earith, including Back Brook, Hall Green Brook, Parsons Drove Drain, Swavesey Drain and Wadsbys Folly. Access to properties in Berry Lane, Godmanchester may also be affected. 

Further rainfall is forecast for Wednesday evening which will keep river levels high. 

Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  

We are monitoring the situation. 

We will update this message by 6pm today, 25/09/2024.

items.description: Middle Avon Rugby to Bidford
items.message: River levels are rising at the Bidford river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible this evening and overnight, 24/09/24. We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Avon between Rugby and Bidford including Warwick, Stratford upon Avon, caravan parks and farmland. No further rainfall is forecast. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 12:00 on 25/09/24, or as the situation changes.

River levels are falling but remain high in response to recent heavy rainfall.  

Flooding is possible for the next few days.    

Areas most at risk are around the River Great Ouse from Newport Pagnell to Roxton.   

Further rainfall is forecast for Wednesday evening which will keep river levels high. 

Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  

We are monitoring the situation. 

We will update this message by 6pm today, 25/09/2024.

items.description: Chertsey Bourne

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels have risen on the Chertsey Bourne as a result of heavy rain over the few days. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected today - 25/09/2024 , especially in the areas closest to the Free Prae Road area of Chertsey.
 Further heavier rainfall is forecast today 25/09/24. River levels are expected to remain high for several days. 
Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 25/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Leadon catchment
items.message:
River levels are falling but remain high at the Wedderburn Bridge river gauge as a result of localised thunderstorms. Consequently, the risk of flooding of roads and farmland is still possible. 
We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leadon. Locations that may be affected include Ledbury, Much Marcle, Staunton and Tibberton. Water may be out of bank at Upleadon Court. 
Further rainfall is forecast in the next 24 hours. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5-day flood forecast and avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow, 26/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn in Gloucestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Tewkesbury Upper Pound river gauge following recent heavy rainfall. 
Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. 
We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. Severn Ham, Tewkesbury starts to fill. 
Predicted peaks: Mythe, Haw Bridge, Sandhurst and Gloucester have all peaked and are steady. 
Further rainfall is forecast in the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5-day flood forecast, and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow, 26/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tributaries on the Upper River Thames above Cricklade

floodArea.riverOrSea: Flagham Brook, Swill Brook, Hankerton Brook, Hykemeres Stream, Derry Brook, River Key

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high but have started to stabilise or fall in some places on the River Key. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue overnight, 25/09/2024, especially in areas closest to the River Key in the Purton Stoke area. Levels on the Swill Brook have risen but remain below the flood risk threshold.
Light showers are forecast today, with heavier rain forecast tomorrow 25/09/24 which could cause further flood impacts.  
Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens in the area and we are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 25/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cole, Dorcan Brook and South Marston Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels have now fallen on the River Cole and Dorcan Brook following yesterday's  heavy rain. No further flooding of low lying land and roads is expected but floodwater may remain in the floodplain especially in rural areas to the north of Swindon. The forecast for the remainder of today is dry, with heavy showers forecast tomorrow 25/09/24. River levels are falling but remain sensitive to any further rainfall. 
Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 25/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is expected. A flood warning is in force for the River Cherwell at Kings Sutton. Levels have started to fall at the top of the catchment but continue to rise in the Kings Sutton and Banbury areas in response to yesterday's heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue. 
No further rainfall is forecast overnight, but heavy showers are expected tomorrow. River levels in the Kings Sutton and Banbury areas are expected to peak overnight as water moves downstream, before falling tomorrow morning.    
Our staff have been checking and clearing trash screens in the area and we are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. items.description: River Adur East Branch
items.message: The River Adur has now fallen significantly. There is uncertainty in the weather forecast, but light rain on Wednesday (25/09/2024) followed by possible heavy showers through the early hours of Thursday could cause river levels to rise again. From 10:00 on 26/09/2024, minor flooding and small amounts of water could affect fields, gardens and possibly the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury. The river should peak lower than it was on Monday, and begin to fall by 22:00 on 26/09/2024. However, it is possible that another period of persistent rain with intense showers could occur throughout Thursday and into Friday (27/09/2024), which would cause river levels to rise higher. There is confidence in less rain occurring from Friday afternoon and through the weekend, which should allow river levels to return nearer to normal by Saturday afternoon at the latest. Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge, may be affected. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 26/09/2024.

Property flooding is expected. River levels are rising on the River Ock as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of properties closest to the river is expected today, 25/09/24, in the Abingdon area. Areas most at risk are Nash Drive, Chaunterell Way,  Mill Paddock, Orpwood Way and St Helens Mill. Further rainfall is forecast today with the potential to be heavy at times. We expect river levels to continue to rise slowly today as levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.
Our staff are liaising with councils and emergency services. We are monitoring the situation. Move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety.  Activate any property flood protection products such as flood barriers. This message will be updated by this evening, 25/09/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thame from Chiselhampton to Drayton St Leonard
items.message:
Property flooding is possible. River levels are rising on the River Thame as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of property and roads is possible this today, 25/09/24, especially in the Stadhampton area. Further rainfall is forecast today with the potential to be heavy at times. We expect river levels to remain high and sensitive to further rainfall. 
Move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by this evening, 25/09/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to Cherwell Bridge
items.message:
Property flooding is expected. River levels are high on the River Cherwell as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of property and roads is expected to continue today, 25/09/24, in the Heyford Bridge and Enslow areas. Areas most at risk include Watermead Road, Kidlington. Further rainfall is forecast today with the potential to be heavy at times. River levels are expected to rise again this afternoon in response to forecast rainfall. 
Our staff are liaising with councils and emergency services. We are monitoring the situation. Move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety. Activate any property flood protection products such as flood barriers. This message will be updated by this evening, 25/09/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray for Islip
items.message:
Property flooding is expected. River levels are rising on the River Ray as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of property and roads is expected today, 25/09/24, especially in the Islip area.  Areas most at risk include Mill Street. Further rainfall is forecast today with the potential to be heavy at times. We expect river levels to continue to rise slowly today and overnight. 
Our staff are liaising with councils and emergency services.  Move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety. Move family, pets and cars to safety. This message will be updated by this evening, 25/09/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray from the Heath Bridge area to and including the Otmoor Basin

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is expected. River levels are rising on the River Ray as a result of very heavy rainfall yesterday. Therefore, flooding of property and roads is expected today, 25/09/24, especially in the Murcott and Otmoor area. Further rainfall is forecast today with the potential to be heavy at times. We expect river levels to continue to rise slowly today and overnight. 
Our staff are liaising with councils and emergency services.  Move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety. Move family, pets and cars to safety. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 25/09/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Low lying areas close to the River Great Ouse and River Ouzel at Newport Pagnell
items.message: River levels are beginning to fall following recent heavy rainfall but remain responsive to further rainfall. Flooding is expected. Areas most at risk are Caldecote Lane, Willen Road, River Side, Toll House, Woad Farm, Sherington Road and Gallards Farm in Newport Pagnell, and Ravenstone Mill in Ravenstone.  Take care on low lying roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 4pm today, 25/09/24.

items.description: Low lying areas close to the River Great Ouse at Fulwell, Radclive and Buckingham
items.message: River levels are now steadily falling, but remain quite high in some locations and responsive to further rainfall. A Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area. The forecast is for further rainfall throughout Wednesday which may cause the river levels to rise again. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.  We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Wider area at risk from the River Great Ouse at Fulwell, Radclive and Buckingham
items.message: River levels are now steadily falling, but remain quite high in some locations and responsive to further rainfall. A Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area. The forecast is for further rainfall throughout Wednesday which may cause the river levels to rise again. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.  We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: River Ock at Abingdon and Caldecott
items.message: Property flooding is expected. River levels are rising on the River Ock as a result of a period of sustained rain. Therefore, flooding of property has already occurred but wider flooding impacts are imminent. Peak levels will be higher than January 2024, however they will be significantly lower than July 2007.  Chauntrelle Way, Orpwood Way and Nash Drive are the most vulnerable.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high today and overnight We are monitoring the situation. Our staff are liaising with councils and emergency services. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.) Move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety and do not drive or walk through flood water. This message will be updated by this afternoon, 25/09/2024, or as the situation changes.
